p: Satellite cloud and precipitation observations tell a coherent story of decreasing ITCZ width and increasing precipitation intensity. These findings from satellite observations are further supported by ocean surface salinity observations. Sea-surface salinity and precipitation minus evaporation ( P − E) are related measures of the hydrological cycle, and there is considerable evidence from ocean observations for a strengthening of the tropical hydrological cycle [ 59– 61]. Long-term trends in salinity show decreases (or freshening) in the Atlantic and Pacific ITCZs but increases along the ITCZ edges [ 60, 62– 64]. The salinity increases in the subtropics and along the ITCZ margins are stronger in the Atlantic, with the freshening more evident in the core of the Pacific ITCZ.
